The Impact of baryonic physics on the kinetic Sunyaev-Zel‚Äôdovich Effect

Abstract

Poorly understood ‚Äúbaryonic physics‚Äù impacts our ability to predict the power spectrum of the kinetic Sunyaev-Zel‚Äôdovich (kSZ) effect. We study this in one sample high resolution simulation of galaxy formation and feedback, Illustris. The high resolution of Illustris allows us to probe the kSZ power spectrum on multipoles ‚Ñì=103‚àí3√ó104‚Ñìsuperscript1033superscript104\ell=10^{3}-3\times 10^{4}. Strong AGN feedback in Illustris nearly wipes out gas fluctuations at k‚â≥1‚Äãh‚ÄãMpc‚àí1greater-than-or-equivalent-toùëò1‚ÑésuperscriptMpc1k\gtrsim 1~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1} and at late times, likely somewhat under predicting the kSZ power generated at z‚â≤1less-than-or-similar-toùëß1z\lesssim 1. The post-reionization kSZ power spectrum for Illustris is well-fit by ùíü‚Ñìz<6=1.38‚Äã[‚Ñì/3000]0.21‚ÄãŒº‚ÄãK2subscriptsuperscriptùíüùëß6‚Ñì1.38superscriptdelimited-[]‚Ñì30000.21ùúásuperscriptùêæ2\mathcal{D}^{z<6}_{\ell}=1.38[\ell/3000]^{0.21}~{}\mu K^{2} over 3000‚â≤‚Ñì‚â≤10000less-than-or-similar-to3000‚Ñìless-than-or-similar-to100003000\lesssim\ell\lesssim 10000, somewhat lower than most other reported values but consistent with the analysis of Shaw et al. Our analysis of the bias of free electrons reveals subtle effects associated with the multi-phase gas physics and stellar fractions that affect even linear scales. In particular there are fewer electrons in biased galaxies, due to gas cooling and star formation, and this leads to an electron bias less than one even at low wavenumbers. The combination of bias and electron fraction that determines the overall suppression is relatively constant, fe2‚Äãbe‚Äã02‚àº0.7similar-tosuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëí2subscriptsuperscriptùëè2ùëí00.7f_{e}^{2}b^{2}_{e0}\sim 0.7, but more simulations are needed to see if this is Illustris-specific. By separating the kSZ power into different terms, we find at least 6‚Äã(10)%6percent106\,(10)\% of the signal at ‚Ñì=3000‚Äã(10000)‚Ñì300010000\ell=3000\,(10000) comes from non-Gaussian connected four-point density and velocity correlations, ‚ü®Œ¥‚Äãv‚ÄãŒ¥‚Äãv‚ü©csubscriptdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùõøùë£ùõøùë£ùëê\left<\delta v\delta v\right>_{c}, even without correcting for the Illustris simulation box size. A challenge going forward will be to accurately model long-wave velocity modes simultaneously with Illustris-like high resolution to capture the complexities of galaxy formation and its correlations with large scale flows.

1. Introduction

The cosmic microwave background (CMB) is a powerful probe of cosmic history through secondary anisotropies generated by free electrons in the intergalactic medium, resulting in a spectral distortion and cluster-concentrated anisotropies from inverse Compton scattering off of hot gas in galaxy clusters, the thermal Sunyaev-Zel‚Äôdovich (tSZ) effect (e.g., Sunyaev and Zeldovich, 1972), and spectrally undistorted temperature anisotropies from Thompson scattering from moving electrons participating in the bulk flow of the medium, the kinetic Sunyeav-Zel‚Äôdovich (kSZ) (e.g., Sunyaev and Zeldovich, 1980) effect.

Of these two, the tSZ effect is much easier to detect because it is determined by electron pressure, which is much higher in clusters. The distinct spectral signature allows it to be separated from other sky signals if observations are made in multiple frequency bands. Because the tSZ effect is dominated by massive clusters, however, it gives a rather biased view of the intergalactic medium, concentrated towards the rarest peaks at relatively late times, z‚â≤1.5less-than-or-similar-toùëß1.5z\lesssim 1.5 (e.g., Komatsu and Seljak, 2002). The kSZ effect, on the other hand, while much more difficult to detect, is affected by all ionized gas regardless of its temperature, providing a more global and unbiased view of the universe during and after reionization. The next generation of ground based CMB surveys, such as the Simons Observatory (SO111http://simonsobservatory.org) and CMB-S4222http://cmb-s4.org (Abazajian et¬†al., 2016) will use the kSZ effect both as a probe of the intergalactic medium (Hern√°ndez-Monteagudo et¬†al., 2015; Schaan et¬†al., 2016; Hill et¬†al., 2016; Soergel et¬†al., 2016; De Bernardis et¬†al., 2017; Battaglia et¬†al., 2017): cosmology with large-scale velocity flows (Mueller et¬†al., 2015a; Sugiyama et¬†al., 2017; Mueller et¬†al., 2015b; Alonso et¬†al., 2016) will soon become a reality.

The kSZ effect can be detected in the cosmic microwave background alone or by cross-correlating it with tracers of large-scale structure such as galaxies and clusters. Cross correlation is done by combining CMB temperature maps with line intensity maps in the EOR (Cooray, 2004; Salvaterra et¬†al., 2005; Alvarez et¬†al., 2006), with projected fields of large scale structure (e.g., Dor√© et¬†al., 2004; Ferraro et¬†al., 2015; Hill et¬†al., 2016), or by stacking on groups and clusters (Schaan et¬†al., 2016; Soergel et¬†al., 2016). These techniques use the fact that the peculiar velocities responsible for the effect are correlated with large scale density fluctuations, while the electron density fluctuations required to avoid line of sight cancellation occur on small scales. This separation of linear velocity modes on large scales and density fluctuation on small scales also greatly simplifies the modeling.

The kSZ effect is quite challenging to detect robustly using CMB temperature measurements alone. On large scales, the power spectrum is subdominant but has the same frequency spectrum as the much stronger primary temperature fluctuations (e.g., Hu and Dodelson, 2002). On smaller scales where it does dominate over the primary, ‚Ñì‚â≥4000greater-than-or-equivalent-to‚Ñì4000\ell\gtrsim 4000, it competes with other secondary signals such as the cosmic infrared background and tSZ, made especially difficult because they will be correlated and there are not enough frequency bands to separate the components in spite of their rather different frequency spectra. Experiments are in development that will help to give the resolution, sensitivity and frequency coverage to make for a very promising kSZ future in observations. There have been detections reported in the literature, the best so far from the South Pole Telescope at a multipole moment of ‚Ñì‚àº3000similar-to‚Ñì3000\ell\sim 3000: ùíü‚Ñì=3000kSZ=2.9¬±1.3‚ÄãŒº‚ÄãK2superscriptsubscriptùíü‚Ñì3000kSZplus-or-minus2.91.3ùúásuperscriptùêæ2\mathcal{D}_{\ell=3000}^{\rm kSZ}=2.9\pm 1.3~{}\mu K^{2} (George et¬†al., 2015), where ùíü‚Ñì‚â°‚Ñì‚Äã(‚Ñì+1)‚ÄãC‚Ñì/2‚ÄãœÄsubscriptùíü‚Ñì‚Ñì‚Ñì1subscriptC‚Ñì2ùúã\mathcal{D}_{\ell}\equiv\ell(\ell+1)\rm{C}_{\ell}/2\pi. However, combining the South Pole Telescope, Atacama Cosmology Telescope and Planck data removes the detection and instead gives an upper bound of ùíü‚Ñì=3000kSZ<1.79‚ÄãŒº‚ÄãK2superscriptsubscriptùíü‚Ñì3000kSZ1.79ùúásuperscriptùêæ2\mathcal{D}_{\ell=3000}^{\rm kSZ}<1.79~{}\mu K^{2} (Planck Collaboration et¬†al., 2016). In future CMB experiments, the kSZ power spectrum should be unveiled by using independent polarization measurements to predict the primary temperature power spectrum and subtract it, leaving the kSZ (Calabrese et¬†al., 2014). Another approach is beyond the 2-point power spectrum, for example correlating with the square of filtered temperature fluctuations (Smith and Ferraro, 2016).

One of the primary reasons such effort is being made to isolate the kSZ contribution from primary fluctuations is to better understand the epoch of reionization. Gas density and velocity fluctuations during reionization had not yet formed nonlinear structure on galaxy and cluster scales, but the patchiness of the reionization process itself created order unity fluctuations in the electron density, and this is predicted to account for half or more of the total kSZ power. A prerequisite step for studying the EOR kSZ signal is to determine better the post-reionization part and subtract it from the total of the two components. Several attempts have been made to translate the observational kSZ limit into a constraint on the timing and duration of reionization (Zahn et¬†al., 2012; Mesinger et¬†al., 2012; Battaglia et¬†al., 2013), although self-regulation of low-mass galaxies (Park et¬†al., 2013) and the highly uncertain dependence on the mean free path of the percolation phase of reionization (Alvarez and Abel, 2012) creates a degeneracy in that parametrization. How to constrain the epoch of reionization with the kSZ signal is only partly understood and is an active area of investigation.

The late-time temperature power spectrum is also the primary statistic that describes the overall scale dependence of fluctuations in the intergalactic medium, and understanding how it depends on baryonic processes in the post-reionization universe is of fundamental importance.

In this paper, we utilize the Illustris simulation (Nelson et¬†al., 2015; Vogelsberger et¬†al., 2013) as a case study for feedback and associated baryonic effects on electron density fluctuations and hence the kSZ power spectrum. Illustris is a recent cosmological hydrodynamic simulation of structure formation with a reasonably large (75‚Äãh‚àí1‚ÄãMpc75superscript‚Ñé1Mpc75~{}h^{-1}~{}\rm{Mpc}) sample volume, which has the advantage of being publicly available with sufficient resolution to probe the multi-phase gas distribution within galaxies and groups on cosmological scales that includes the important effects determining the distribution of electrons, such as feedback from star formation and AGNs. The dark matter particle number and initial gas mesh number is (1820)3superscript18203(1820)^{3}, sufficient to resolve the small-scale impact on the kSZ effect.

The kSZ signal is a line of sight integral of ‚àíŒ≥^‚ãÖœÉT‚Äãne‚ÄãùêØe‚ãÖ^ùõæsubscriptùúéùëásubscriptùëõùëísubscriptùêØùëí-\hat{\gamma}\cdot\sigma_{T}n_{e}\mathbf{v}_{e}, where nesubscriptùëõùëín_{e} is the electron density, ùêØesubscriptùêØùëí\mathbf{v}_{e} its peculiar velocity, ‚àíŒ≥^^ùõæ-\hat{\gamma} is the photon direction (towards us), and œÉTsubscriptùúéùëá\sigma_{T} is the Thompson cross section. In addition to using Illustris to better understand how electron density fluctuations evolve over time and are biased with respect to the dark matter, we also investigate the contribution of the 4-point connected component on the power spectrum, a decidedly nonlinear effect. The current ne‚ÄãùêØesubscriptùëõùëísubscriptùêØùëín_{e}\mathbf{v}_{e} can be decomposed into the gradient of a potential and the curl of a vector. In Fourier space, the gradient term is along the direction of the wavenumber, whereas the curl piece is perpendicular to it. The gradient component gives the linear components from recombination familiar from primary CMB anisotropies, but the kSZ power spectrum is primarily sourced by fluctuations in the curl component, ùê™‚üÇ=[ùêØe‚Äã(1+Œ¥e)]‚üÇsubscriptùê™perpendicular-tosubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùêØùëí1subscriptùõøùëíperpendicular-to\mathbf{q_{\perp}}=[\mathbf{v}_{e}(1+\delta_{e})]_{\perp}. For full ionization, this is the transverse momentum field of the gas. The vorticity of the gas becomes nonzero when shocks occur, but is sub-dominant in its influence. Since our focus here is on the kSZ power spectrum, we want to study the power spectrum of ùê™‚üÇ=[ùêØe‚ÄãŒ¥e]‚üÇsubscriptùê™perpendicular-tosubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùêØùëísubscriptùõøùëíperpendicular-to\mathbf{q_{\perp}}=[\mathbf{v}_{e}\delta_{e}]_{\perp} in order to model the signal. Schematically this power spectrum is a four-point function of two densities and velocities, which can be decomposed into an unconnected part, involving the sum of products of two-point functions and a connected 4-point function, ‚ü®Œ¥‚Äãv‚ÄãŒ¥‚Äãv‚ü©csubscriptdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùõøùë£ùõøùë£ùëê\left<\delta v\delta v\right>_{c}: ‚ü®q‚Äãq‚ü©=‚ü®Œ¥‚ÄãŒ¥‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®v‚Äãv‚ü©+2‚Äã‚ü®Œ¥‚Äãv‚ü©2+‚ü®Œ¥‚Äãv‚ÄãŒ¥‚Äãv‚ü©cdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùëûùëûdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùõøùõødelimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùë£ùë£2superscriptdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùõøùë£2subscriptdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùõøùë£ùõøùë£ùëê\left<qq\right>=\left<\delta\delta\right>\left<vv\right>+2\left<\delta v\right>^{2}+\left<\delta v\delta v\right>_{c}. The connected term arises when the density or velocity field becomes non-Gaussian.

Early analytic work focused on the linear regime calculation in which the density and velocity fields are Gaussian-distributed and the connected term does not exist (Ostriker and Vishniac, 1986; Vishniac, 1987; Dodelson and Jubas, 1995; Jaffe and Kamionkowski, 1998). Later, calculations for the nonlinear density field were done by replacing the linear density power spectrum in the expression for the unconnected part, but the connected term was ignored (Hu, 2000; Ma and Fry, 2002; Zhang et¬†al., 2004; Shaw et¬†al., 2012). Recently, a few studies reported that the connected term can add a significant amount of power in the cases where the density field becomes highly non-Gaussian. Park et¬†al. (2016)(hereafter P16) showed that nonlinear growth of structure can introduce ‚àº30%similar-toabsentpercent30\sim 30\% extra momentum power at k‚àº1‚ÄãMpc‚àí1similar-toùëò1superscriptMpc1k\sim 1~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1}, leading to ‚àº10%similar-toabsentpercent10\sim 10\% more post-reionization kSZ signal. For incomplete ionization during the reionization epoch, the ionization fraction is also associated with correlated processes distinct from the gas density, which should be described as a 6-point function and is almost impossible to estimate except through simulation. Alvarez (2016) measured a ‚àº30%similar-toabsentpercent30\sim 30\% excess kSZ signal from the patchy ionized density field in their epoch of reionization simulation. It is reasonable to expect the baryonic physics would add to the non-Gaussianity in the plasma density field. We aim to confirm that hypothesis in this work. Maps made of the kSZ effect with concentrated regions of electron density in groups and clusters and with velocities self-consistently included have for a long time included aspects of the nonzero connected 4-point pieces.

The paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we express the kSZ signal in terms of transverse momentum power spectrum and describe how the unconnected terms of transverse momentum power spectrum are related to the density and velocity power spectra. In Section 3, we describe the Illustris simulation, which we will mainly use for our analyses. In Section 4, we quantify how the baryonic physics affect the plasma density power spectra, and contrast it with the momentum power for dark matter. We then measure the contribution of the connected term in the transverse momentum power spectrum from the simulation. We also report the post-reionization kSZ signal from the simulation along with values reported by other recent works. In section 5, we summarize and discuss our results.

2. The KSZ signal from the Post-reionization Era

2.2. Power Spectrum of the Transverse Momentum Field

Here, we shall summarize the derivation of Pq‚üÇsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} in terms of the density and velocity power spectra. In Fourier space

While linear calculations are accurate enough for Pv‚ÄãvsubscriptùëÉùë£ùë£P_{vv}, we need a more accurate PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥subscriptùëÉùõøùõøP_{\delta\delta} to account for nonlinear effects at high kùëòk‚Äôs.

At z‚â≤3less-than-or-similar-toùëß3z\lesssim 3 and k>1‚Äãh‚ÄãMpc‚àí1ùëò1‚ÑésuperscriptMpc1k>1~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1}, PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥subscriptùëÉùõøùõøP_{\delta\delta} is strongly affected by both the growth of nonlinear structure, which can differ for gas cf. dark matter, and the baryonic physics operating. We characterize how the electron density power PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥esubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëíùõøùõøP^{e}_{\delta\delta} differs from the dark matter power PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥dsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëëùõøùõøP^{d}_{\delta\delta} by a scale and redshift dependent bias, defined here by

be‚Äã(k,z)‚â°PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥e‚Äã(k,z)PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥d‚Äã(k,z).subscriptùëèùëíùëòùëßsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëíùõøùõøùëòùëßsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëëùõøùõøùëòùëß\displaystyle b_{e}(k,z)\equiv\sqrt{\frac{P^{e}_{\delta\delta}(k,z)}{P^{d}_{\delta\delta}(k,z)}}. (10)

To see the combined effects in both fesubscriptùëìùëíf_{e} and Pq‚üÇsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}}, Shaw et¬†al. (2012) (hereafter SRN12) introduced a window function,

We2‚Äã(k,z)‚â°fe2‚Äã(z)‚Äãbe2‚Äã(k,z),superscriptsubscriptùëäùëí2ùëòùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëí2ùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëí2ùëòùëß\displaystyle W_{e}^{2}(k,z)\equiv f_{e}^{2}(z)b_{e}^{2}(k,z), (11)

which we adopt in this work to describe the baryonic effects.

We note that Pq‚üÇ,u‚ÄãcsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùë¢ùëêP_{q_{\perp},uc} does not fully account for Pq‚üÇsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} in the nonlinear regime due to the rise of the connected term, Pq‚üÇ,csubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùëêP_{q_{\perp},c}. P16 confirmed that it is present and important to include for the pure dark matter momentum field. We find the connected term is still important for the electrons, but differs in detail because of the relative bias.

3. Simulation

For our analysis of the power, and its deconstruction into connected and unconnected parts, we use the publicly available results from Illustris, a hydrodynamic simulation of galaxy formation from cosmological initial conditions in a (75‚Äãh‚àí1‚ÄãMpc)3superscript75superscript‚Ñé1Mpc3(75~{}h^{-1}~{}\rm{Mpc})^{3} comoving volume periodic box. Its hydrodynamics and gravitational dynamics are driven by the moving mesh code, AREPO (Springel, 2010). It uses sub-grid prescriptions for chemical cooling of the gas, subsequent star and black-hole formation, and the feedback of stars and black-holes on the surrounding medium. The details of the sub-grid models are described in Vogelsberger et¬†al. (2013) and Torrey et¬†al. (2014). The simulation starts with 18203superscript182031820^{3} dark matter particles, each having 6.26√ó106‚ÄãM‚äô6.26superscript106subscriptùëÄdirect-product6.26\times 10^{6}~{}M_{\odot}. The number of resolution elements for the gas is the same, with the initial mass of 1.26√ó106‚ÄãM‚äô1.26superscript106subscriptùëÄdirect-product1.26\times 10^{6}~{}M_{\odot}. This setup allows halos to be resolved down to 108‚ÄãM‚òâsuperscript108subscriptùëÄ‚òâ10^{8}~{}M_{\sun} in mass, and power spectra to be reliable up to k‚àº10‚Äãh‚ÄãMpc‚àí1similar-toùëò10‚ÑésuperscriptMpc1k\sim 10~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1} in wavenumber. The cosmology is based on a tilted ŒõŒõ\LambdaCDM model with Œ©m=0.2726subscriptŒ©ùëö0.2726\Omega_{m}=0.2726, h=0.704‚Ñé0.704h=0.704, Œ©b=0.0456subscriptŒ©ùëè0.0456\Omega_{b}=0.0456, œÉ8=0.809subscriptùúé80.809\sigma_{8}=0.809, and ns=0.963subscriptùëõùë†0.963n_{s}=0.963.

Illustris aims to provide a realistic sample of the universe by matching galactic properties with observation. Halos in Illustris are identified by a standard friends-of-friends (FoF) algorithm with linking length b=0.2ùëè0.2b=0.2. Then the SUBFIND algorithm of Springel et¬†al. (2001) is used to identify subhalos, which are regarded as galaxies. Illustris is known to reproduce the stellar mass function and the luminosity function of galaxies reasonably well and results in a realistic morphological composition of galaxies. The key results from Illustris on galactic properties are discussed in Vogelsberger et¬†al. (2014) and Genel et¬†al. (2014).

The snapshots of Illustris are readily available on the web. We use particle snapshots for z=0,0.5,1,2,3,4,ùëß00.51234z=0,0.5,1,2,3,4, and 555 in this work. The snapshots contains masses, locations and velocities of dark and gas particles, and free electron fractions, required for computing the transverse momentum power spectra of the species present.

4. Results

4.1. Density Power Spectrum of Dark Matter and Free Electron

We show the power spectra of dark matter (PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥dsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëëùõøùõøP^{d}_{\delta\delta}) and free electron (PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥esubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëíùõøùõøP^{e}_{\delta\delta}) density fields in the right panels of Figure¬†1 for z=0,1,3,ùëß013z=0,~{}1,~{}3, and 5. Nonlinearity results in the familiar result of PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥dsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëëùõøùõøP^{d}_{\delta\delta} growing faster than the linear theory prediction. At k>1‚Äãh‚ÄãMpc‚àí1ùëò1‚ÑésuperscriptMpc1k>1~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1}, PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥dsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëëùõøùõøP^{d}_{\delta\delta} is about an order of magnitude larger than the linear prediction at z=0ùëß0z=0. As is well known from previous works, the HALOFIT model of Smith et¬†al. (2003) does a good job in modeling this enhancement. The evolution of PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥esubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëíùõøùõøP^{e}_{\delta\delta}, however, is more complicated, showing the effects of dynamical nonlinear growth at z‚â•3ùëß3z\geq 3, but complicated by separation of gas from baryons by shocking and feedback, combining to give a growth slower than linear after z=3ùëß3z=3. How this difference between PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥dsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëëùõøùõøP^{d}_{\delta\delta} and PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥esubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëíùõøùõøP^{e}_{\delta\delta} arises due to the effects of baryonic physics of plasma is what we aim to probe.

A list of relevant baryonic physics that will impact the free electrons relative to the dark matter are:

  • 1)

    Collapse of cooled gas

  • 2)

    Star-formation converting gas into stars and blackholes

  • 3)

    AGN feedback blowing gas out of potential wells

  • 4)

    Self-shielding of cold neutral gas in galaxies against ionizing radiation

  • 5)

    He II reionization at z‚àº3similar-toùëß3z\sim 3

For example, the density map of free electron in comparison to that of dark matter (See the left panels of Figure¬†1) shows the smoothing of the electron density field at ùíõ‚â§ùüèùíõ1\bm{z\leq 1} at certain scales that we can attribute to the effect of AGN feedback. The spread extends over larger scales than in some other gasdynamical calculations, a consequence of the strong feedback in Illustris. This explains the deficit in PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥esubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëíùõøùõøP^{e}_{\delta\delta} compared to PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥dsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëëùõøùõøP^{d}_{\delta\delta} at high kùëòk and low redshift. To further analyze the differences, we now explore the window function WesubscriptùëäùëíW_{e} (Eq.¬†11).

4.2. Window Functions of Baryon, Gas, and Free Electrons

The window function for the free electrons relative to dark matter WesubscriptùëäùëíW_{e} encodes the effect of all of the baryonic physics relevant to the intergalactic plasma. To help deconstruct its shape we explore equivalent window functions for baryons (WbsubscriptùëäùëèW_{b}) and gas (WgsubscriptùëäùëîW_{g}) as well, defined similarly to WesubscriptùëäùëíW_{e}, except that we use baryon and gas densities are used instead of electron number density in Equation¬†(2). The baryon density field includes all the mass in stars, AGNs and neutral gas as well as gas and we can thus use it to exclude the effect of converting gas into those elements that do not give rise to the kSZ effect. The gas density field does include neutral gas in galaxies, but not stars or AGNs, which allows us to decompose the effect of having multiphase gas. We show Wb,Wg,subscriptùëäùëèsubscriptùëäùëîW_{b},~{}W_{g}, and WesubscriptùëäùëíW_{e} in Figure¬†3 for z=0,0.5,1,2,ùëß00.512z=0,~{}0.5,~{}1,~{}2, and 4.

In WbsubscriptùëäùëèW_{b} an up-turn appears at k‚àº5‚Äãh‚ÄãMpc‚àí1similar-toùëò5‚ÑésuperscriptMpc1k\sim 5~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1} at all redshifts shown, a trend easily understood by the collapse of gas on small scales following gas cooling in over-dense regions. At z‚â§2ùëß2z\leq 2, the feedback of star-formation and AGNs heats the gas and makes it expand over time, damping WbsubscriptùëäùëèW_{b} at k‚â≥0.3‚Äãh‚ÄãMpc‚àí1greater-than-or-equivalent-toùëò0.3‚ÑésuperscriptMpc1k\gtrsim 0.3~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1}. The combination of these two effects creates a dipper-like shape in Wb2superscriptsubscriptùëäùëè2W_{b}^{2} at z‚â§1ùëß1z\leq 1.

The comparison of WgsubscriptùëäùëîW_{g} to WbsubscriptùëäùëèW_{b} demonstrates the effect of star-formation. As gas is converted into stars in density peaks, gas density power is strongly suppressed at k‚â≥1‚Äãh‚ÄãMpc‚àí1greater-than-or-equivalent-toùëò1‚ÑésuperscriptMpc1k\gtrsim 1~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1}. As a result, the up-turn at high-kùëòk is much weaker in WgsubscriptùëäùëîW_{g}. Additionally, star-formation suppresses WgsubscriptùëäùëîW_{g} at all wavenumbers as can be seen from the low-kùëòk limit of Wg2subscriptsuperscriptùëä2ùëîW^{2}_{g} being less than one. For the case in which a fraction (1‚àífg)1subscriptùëìùëî(1-f_{g}) of gas was of converted into stars homogeneously, Wg2superscriptsubscriptùëäùëî2W_{g}^{2} would be suppressed by a factor of fg2superscriptsubscriptùëìùëî2f_{g}^{2}. In Illustris we find Wg2subscriptsuperscriptùëä2ùëîW^{2}_{g} drops below fg2superscriptsubscriptùëìùëî2f_{g}^{2} at low kùëòk because star-formation drains gas preferentially in over-densities and create an anti-bias in the gas density field. The bias of the gas density bgsubscriptùëèùëîb_{g} shown in the middle right panel of Figure¬†3 clearly shows this anti-biasing effect in its low-kùëòk limit. To extract the anti-bias, we define bg‚Äã0subscriptùëèùëî0b_{g0} as Wg‚Äã(k‚Üí0)subscriptùëäùëî‚Üíùëò0W_{g}(k\rightarrow 0). In Figure¬†4 we plot bg‚Äã02subscriptsuperscriptùëè2ùëî0b^{2}_{g0}, fg2subscriptsuperscriptùëì2ùëîf^{2}_{g}, fg2‚Äãbg‚Äã02subscriptsuperscriptùëì2ùëîsubscriptsuperscriptùëè2ùëî0f^{2}_{g}b^{2}_{g0} and their counterparts for electron density. Due to ongoing star-formation, fg2subscriptsuperscriptùëì2ùëîf^{2}_{g} monotonically decreases from 0.92 to 0.8 between z=5ùëß5z=5 and 00. bg2superscriptsubscriptùëèùëî2b_{g}^{2} starts from 0.96 at z=0ùëß0z=0 and decreases until z=1ùëß1z=1 down to 0.92 and stays without much change until z=0ùëß0z=0. The combination of these two term, fg2‚Äãbg‚Äã02subscriptsuperscriptùëì2ùëîsubscriptsuperscriptùëè2ùëî0f^{2}_{g}b^{2}_{g0}, gives a large-scale suppression effect that grows from 5%percent55\% to 20%percent2020\% between z=5ùëß5z=5 and 00.

WesubscriptùëäùëíW_{e} has additional suppression effects on top of what it inherits from WgsubscriptùëäùëîW_{g} because not all electrons that survived star-formation contribute to the mean ionized plasma: a significant fraction of them are trapped in the cold neutral gas in galaxies that remains self-shielded from extragalactic ionizing radiation or are locked in helium atoms at z‚â≥3greater-than-or-equivalent-toùëß3z\gtrsim 3 where most heliums are only singly ionized even when hydrogen is ionized. Similarly to the comparison of WgsubscriptùëäùëîW_{g} to WbsubscriptùëäùëèW_{b}, WesubscriptùëäùëíW_{e} gets an all-wavenumber suppression plus more high-kùëòk suppression compared to WgsubscriptùëäùëîW_{g}, which makes We<WgsubscriptùëäùëísubscriptùëäùëîW_{e}<W_{g} at all scales. The filled circles on the curves for WesubscriptùëäùëíW_{e} denote the wavenumber that contributes mostly to the ‚Ñì=3000‚Ñì3000\ell=3000 signal at give zùëßz, ‚Ñì/s‚Äã(z)‚Ñìùë†ùëß\ell/s(z). Those circles show that the signal down to z=2ùëß2z=2 is mostly affected by the large-scale term fg2‚Äãbg‚Äã02subscriptsuperscriptùëì2ùëîsubscriptsuperscriptùëè2ùëî0f^{2}_{g}b^{2}_{g0} and the z<2ùëß2z<2 signal is further suppressed by the AGN feedback.

This is a nonlinear relationship which involves averaging over constrained probability functionals to yield ‚ü®Œ¥e‚Äã(ùê±)|Œ¥d‚ü©inner-productsubscriptùõøùëíùê±subscriptùõøùëë\langle\delta_{e}(\mathbf{x})|\delta_{d}\rangle and ‚ü®Œ¥g‚Äã(ùê±)|Œ¥d‚ü©inner-productsubscriptùõøùëîùê±subscriptùõøùëë\langle\delta_{g}(\mathbf{x})|\delta_{d}\rangle. However there is a ‚Äúlinear response‚Äù limit in which, e.g.,

œáe‚Äãd‚Äã(ùê±‚àíùê±‚Ä≤)subscriptùúíùëíùëëùê±superscriptùê±‚Ä≤\displaystyle\chi_{ed}(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}) =[‚ü®Œ¥e‚ÄãŒ¥d‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®Œ¥d‚ÄãŒ¥d‚ü©‚àí1]‚Äã(ùê±‚àíùê±‚Ä≤).absentdelimited-[]delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùõøùëísubscriptùõøùëësuperscriptdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùõøùëësubscriptùõøùëë1ùê±superscriptùê±‚Ä≤\displaystyle=[\langle\delta_{e}\delta_{d}\rangle\langle\delta_{d}\delta_{d}\rangle^{-1}](\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime})\,.

The (suitably normalized) susceptibility of nesubscriptùëõùëín_{e} to œÅdsubscriptùúåùëë\rho_{d} is œáe‚Äãdsubscriptùúíùëíùëë\chi_{ed}, with units of inverse volume; the name is chosen because there is a clear relation to the familiar susceptibilities that relate electric and magnetic polarizabilities to applied electromagnetic fields, ultimately leading to dielectric tensors. Another terminology for œáe‚Äãdsubscriptùúíùëíùëë\chi_{ed} is response function, for obvious reasons.

In the halo model expansion for the dark matter density, there are susceptibilities for each class of halo, giving the response of Œ¥dsubscriptùõøùëë\delta_{d} to Mh‚ÄãnhsubscriptùëÄ‚Ñésubscriptùëõ‚ÑéM_{h}n_{h}, where MhsubscriptùëÄ‚ÑéM_{h} is the halo mass and nhsubscriptùëõ‚Ñén_{h} the halo number density for that class. In that case, the susceptibilities give the (suitably normalized) mean dark matter profile of the halo class. Usually scalings are done to take out the dominant dependences on the overall size of the halo (or equivalently the overall mass). Thus these ideas are familiar. The Fourier transform œá~e‚Äãh‚Äã(k)subscript~ùúíùëí‚Ñéùëò\tilde{\chi}_{eh}(k) is the electron density form factor of the halo.

We can relate these ideas to what is done in practice to make mock maps of the kSZ effect, e.g., in the peak patch approach for creating deep all-sky halo catalogs Bond (1996), Bond and Myers (1996), and Alvarez et¬†al. (2017), with analytic or measured susceptibilities used to ‚Äùpaint on‚Äù the electron density profiles around halos. The velocities for the halos are automatic outputs in the peak patch catalog, suitably smoothed over the cluster scale, which changes from cluster to cluster. In Alvarez et¬†al. (2017) the susceptibilities are determined by measurement in the BBPS cosmic hydro simulations of Battaglia et¬†al. (2012), constructing stacked profiles for halos with specified mass and redshift bins, each bin defining a halo-class. The product of the electron density profile and the velocity allows for all-sky mocks of the kSZ effect. The accuracy of the mock then depends upon the magnitude of the residual fluctuations about the mean-field linear-response expansion inherent in this ‚Äúhalo model‚Äù for nesubscriptùëõùëín_{e}.

The Illustris simulations could also be used to calculate the electron density response for each of the halo bins, and be incorporated into the peak-patch simulator in the same way as the BBPS calculations have been. The resolution of Illustris was much superior to BBPS, which has allowed us to study here the influence of galactic-scale baryonic physics that are not resolved in the BBPS simulations, although star and AGN feedback were incorporated. On the other hand, the Illustris box was smaller, and only one box was run, limiting statistical inferences. Thus in Illustris the rare-mass clusters are fewer, exacerbated because there was only one realization. (BBPS ran a (small) ensemble of simulations.) While we await more and larger Illustris and other high resolution simulations for susceptibility measurements, we shall content ourselves here with œáe‚Äãdsubscriptùúíùëíùëë\chi_{ed} measurements, estimated by cross-correlations weighted by the inverse of the self-clustering correlation matrix for dark matter <Œ¥e‚ÄãŒ¥d>‚Äã<Œ¥d‚ÄãŒ¥d>‚àí1expectationsubscriptùõøùëísubscriptùõøùëësuperscriptexpectationsubscriptùõøùëësubscriptùõøùëë1<\delta_{e}\delta_{d}><\delta_{d}\delta_{d}>^{-1}:

œá~e‚Äãd‚Äã(k)=PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥e‚Äãd‚Äã(k)/PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥d‚Äã(k).subscript~ùúíùëíùëëùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëíùëëùõøùõøùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëëùõøùõøùëò\displaystyle\tilde{\chi}_{ed}(k)=P^{ed}_{\delta\delta}(k)/P^{d}_{\delta\delta}(k). (13)

For halos œá~d‚Äãh‚Äã(k)subscript~ùúíùëë‚Ñéùëò\tilde{\chi}_{dh}(k) approaches a mass-weighted anti-bias bd‚Äãh‚Äã0subscriptùëèùëë‚Ñé0b_{dh0} for the halo-class in question at low kùëòk, Œ¥d‚àºŒ¥h/bh‚Äãd‚Äã0similar-tosubscriptùõøùëësubscriptùõø‚Ñésubscriptùëè‚Ñéùëë0\delta_{d}\sim\delta_{h}/b_{hd0}, with bh‚Äãd‚Äã0=œá~h‚Äãd‚Äã(k‚Üí0)subscriptùëè‚Ñéùëë0subscript~ùúí‚Ñéùëë‚Üíùëò0b_{hd0}=\tilde{\chi}_{hd}(k\rightarrow 0) the usual mass-halo dependent bias of halos relative to dark matter density, with bh‚Äãd‚Äã0>1subscriptùëè‚Ñéùëë01b_{hd0}>1. By analogy, we can think of the dimensionless œá~e‚Äãd‚Äã(k)subscript~ùúíùëíùëëùëò\tilde{\chi}_{ed}(k) as the scale-dependent bias of electron density relative to dark matter density.

In the susceptibility language, be2=PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥e/PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥d=œá~e‚Äãd‚Äã(k)/œá~d‚Äãe‚Äã(k)subscriptsuperscriptùëè2ùëísubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëíùõøùõøsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëëùõøùõøsubscript~ùúíùëíùëëùëòsubscript~ùúíùëëùëíùëòb^{2}_{e}=P^{e}_{\delta\delta}/P^{d}_{\delta\delta}=\tilde{\chi}_{ed}(k)/\tilde{\chi}_{de}(k), hence asymptotically approaches be‚Äãd‚Äã0/bd‚Äãe‚Äã0subscriptùëèùëíùëë0subscriptùëèùëëùëí0b_{ed0}/b_{de0}. Although naive biasing prescriptions would suggest this approaches be‚Äãd‚Äã02superscriptsubscriptùëèùëíùëë02b_{ed0}^{2}, in practice it is not quite true: we do not have œá~d‚Äãe‚Äã(k)=1/œá~e‚Äãd‚Äã(k)subscript~ùúíùëëùëíùëò1subscript~ùúíùëíùëëùëò\tilde{\chi}_{de}(k)=1/\tilde{\chi}_{ed}(k), so besubscriptùëèùëíb_{e} also does not reduce to the biasing factor of eùëíe relative to dùëëd. However as we show in Fig.¬†5 the basic features of besubscriptùëèùëíb_{e} look rather similar to those of œá~e‚Äãdsubscript~ùúíùëíùëë\tilde{\chi}_{ed}, though with different high kùëòk suppression behavior.

4.4. Connected Term in Free Electron Transverse Momentum Power Spectrum

Pq‚üÇ,u‚ÄãcsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùë¢ùëêP_{q_{\perp},uc} (Eq.¬†9) was often assumed to represent the complete Pq‚üÇsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} in previous literature. SRN12 and Zhang et¬†al. (2004) showed that evaluating Equation¬†(9) using density power spectrum from simulations and directly computing Pq‚üÇsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} gave nearly similar results. P16 recently revisited that comparison with a pure dark matter simulation and found that Pq‚üÇsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} can be larger than Pq‚üÇ,u‚ÄãcsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùë¢ùëêP_{q_{\perp},uc} up to ‚àº30%similar-toabsentpercent30\sim 30\% at k‚â≥1‚Äãh‚ÄãMpc‚àí1greater-than-or-equivalent-toùëò1‚ÑésuperscriptMpc1k\gtrsim 1~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1} due to the connected term in Pq‚üÇsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} arising in the nonlinear regime. We shall check on this issue for the free electron momentum field here.

To measure Pq‚üÇsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} directly from Illustris, we first assign the velocity-weighted electron number of each particle to a nearest grid in a 5123superscript5123512^{3} mesh. Taking the power spectrum of this mesh would however underestimate Pq‚üÇsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} because it misses velocity modes larger than the size of the simulation box (75‚Äãh‚àí1‚ÄãMpc75superscript‚Ñé1Mpc75~{}h^{-1}~{}\rm{Mpc}) and we thus need to correct for the missing velocity modes not included in the box. We describe how we estimate the correction for those missing modes in the Appendix and show the expression in Equation¬†(A1). In the rest of the paper, we shall use the missing-power-correction-added power spectrum in the analysis and denote it as Pq‚üÇ,t‚Äão‚ÄãtsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùë°ùëúùë°P_{q_{\perp},tot}.

In Figure¬†6, we plot the ratio of Pq‚üÇ,t‚Äão‚ÄãtsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùë°ùëúùë°P_{q_{\perp},tot}, and the unconnected part of the spectrum, Pq‚üÇ,u‚ÄãcsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùë¢ùëêP_{q_{\perp},uc}, to see if Pq‚üÇ,u‚ÄãcsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùë¢ùëêP_{q_{\perp},uc} can fully explains the spectrum. Pq‚üÇ,u‚ÄãcsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùë¢ùëêP_{q_{\perp},uc} is calculated by evaluating Equation¬†(9) with the density and velocity power spectra of Illustris. We focus on the higher k>0.5‚Äãh‚ÄãMpc‚àí1ùëò0.5‚ÑésuperscriptMpc1k>0.5~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1} wavenumbers where the kSZ signal is quite relevant and the number of plane-waves in the simulation box are sufficient for good statistically sampling.

At z=47ùëß47z=47 where the dark matter density and velocity fluctuations are in the linear regime, Pq‚üÇ,t‚Äão‚ÄãtsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùë°ùëúùë°P_{q_{\perp},tot} agrees with Pq‚üÇ,u‚ÄãcsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùë¢ùëêP_{q_{\perp},uc} within a percent. At z‚â§4ùëß4z\leq 4, Pq‚üÇ,t‚Äão‚ÄãtsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùë°ùëúùë°P_{q_{\perp},tot} shows some excess power at k‚â≥1‚Äãh‚ÄãMpc‚àí1greater-than-or-equivalent-toùëò1‚ÑésuperscriptMpc1k\gtrsim 1~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1}. The excess grows monotonically toward low-zùëßz. At z‚â§1ùëß1z\leq 1, the growth of the excess power is much faster for the free electron case than in the dark matter case, which we attribute to the baryonic physics adding more non-Gaussianity to the free electron density field. We interpret this excess power,

Pq‚üÇ,c‚â°Pq‚üÇ,t‚Äão‚Äãt‚àíPq‚üÇ,u‚Äãc,subscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùëêsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùë°ùëúùë°subscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùë¢ùëê\displaystyle P_{q_{\perp},c}\equiv P_{q_{\perp},tot}-P_{q_{\perp},uc}, (14)

as the contribution from the connected term. We note that this is only a conservative lower-bound since we have made no missing power correction for Pq‚üÇ,csubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùëêP_{q_{\perp},c}. If we allow for the same fraction of missing power as in Pq‚üÇ,u‚ÄãcsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùë¢ùëêP_{q_{\perp},uc}, the estimated Pq‚üÇ,csubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùëêP_{q_{\perp},c} would nearly double, but the way the waves enter into the 4-point function precludes that being an accurate correction. We discuss how much Pq‚üÇ,csubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùëêP_{q_{\perp},c} adds to the integrated kSZ signal in the next section.

4.5. Angular Power Spectrum of the kSZ effect

We evaluate Equation¬†(4) using Pq‚üÇ,t‚Äão‚ÄãtsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùë°ùëúùë°P_{q_{\perp},tot} to calculate the kSZ signal from the post-reionization era, ùíü‚ÑìkSZ,z<6subscriptsuperscriptùíükSZùëß6‚Ñì\mathcal{D}^{{\rm kSZ},z<6}_{\ell}, for several different models and present it in Figure¬†7. We also list ùíü‚ÑìkSZ,z<6subscriptsuperscriptùíükSZùëß6‚Ñì\mathcal{D}^{{\rm kSZ},z<6}_{\ell} at ‚Ñì=3000‚Ñì3000\ell=3000 and 100001000010000 in Table¬†1. For models that do not use the free electron density power spectrum, we assume an instantaneous helium reionization at z=3ùëß3z=3 (i.e. helium is singly ionized at 3‚â§z‚â§63ùëß63\leq z\leq 6 and doubly ionized at z<3ùëß3z<3). We describe the models below.

For the leading order (LO) model, we set fe=1subscriptùëìùëí1f_{e}=1 and use Pq‚üÇ,u‚ÄãcsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùë¢ùëêP_{q_{\perp},uc} given by linear PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥subscriptùëÉùõøùõøP_{\delta\delta} and Pv‚ÄãvsubscriptùëÉùë£ùë£P_{vv}. This model excludes all the nonlinear effects in the momentum field and is often referred to as the Ostriker-Vishniac spectrum in the literature (Efstathiou and Bond, 1987; Vishniac, 1987) and gives ùíü‚ÑìkSZ,z<6=1.26‚àí0.85‚ÄãŒº‚ÄãK2subscriptsuperscriptùíükSZùëß6‚Ñì1.260.85ùúásuperscriptùêæ2\mathcal{D}^{{\rm kSZ},z<6}_{\ell}=1.26-0.85~{}\mu K^{2} at ‚Ñì=3000‚àí10000‚Ñì300010000\ell=3000-10000.

For the DM model, we set fe=1subscriptùëìùëí1f_{e}=1 and use the dark matter momentum power spectrum from the simulation. The distribution of dark matter is not strongly affected by the baryonic physics except at short scales. We can thus assume this model predominantly shows the effect of nonlinear growth of structure and not the effect of baryonic physics. Compared to in the LO model, the kSZ signal is enhanced to 3.83‚àí4.26‚ÄãŒº‚ÄãK23.834.26ùúásuperscriptùêæ23.83-4.26~{}\mu K^{2} at ‚Ñì=3000‚àí10000‚Ñì300010000\ell=3000-10000.

The Gas and FE models shown denote the cases for which we use gas and free electron momentum power spectrum, respectively. We use fgsubscriptùëìùëîf_{g} instead of fesubscriptùëìùëíf_{e} for the Gas model and the true value of fesubscriptùëìùëíf_{e} for the FE model. The FE model is the main result of this work. Compared to in the DM model, the kSZ signal at ‚Ñì=3000‚àí10000‚Ñì300010000\ell=3000-10000 is suppressed to ‚àº60‚àí50%similar-toabsent60percent50\sim 60-50\% in the Gas model and ‚àº50‚àí40%similar-toabsent50percent40\sim 50-40\% in the FE model. Considering that, the all-wavenumber suppression factor f2‚Äãb02superscriptùëì2subscriptsuperscriptùëè20f^{2}b^{2}_{0} is ‚àº0.9similar-toabsent0.9\sim 0.9 and 0.70.70.7 for the Gas and FE models (See Fig.¬†4), whereas the high-kùëòk suppression seems to give an extra ‚àº30‚Äã(40)%similar-toabsent30percent40\sim 30(40)\% suppression for ‚Ñì=3000‚Äã(10000)‚Ñì300010000\ell=3000\,(10000). The difference between the Gas and FE models is thus attributable to the difference between fg2‚Äãbg‚Äã02superscriptsubscriptùëìùëî2superscriptsubscriptùëèùëî02f_{g}^{2}b_{g0}^{2} and fe2‚Äãbe‚Äã02superscriptsubscriptùëìùëí2superscriptsubscriptùëèùëí02f_{e}^{2}b_{e0}^{2}.

For the FE model, we show how much is contributed by the connected term by computing the kSZ signal from Pq‚üÇ,csubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toùëêP_{q_{\perp},c}. We refer to this case as the ‚ÄòC‚Äô model. The result shows that the connected term contributes 6‚àí11%6percent116-11\% to the signal at ‚Ñì=3000‚àí10000‚Ñì300010000\ell=3000-10000. As mentioned in the previous section, the connected term may have been underestimated due to the finite box-size of the simulation, possibly even by factor of a few.

with

for the fitting function. In Figure¬†8, we describe how the kSZ signal accumulates over redshift for each model by plotting d‚Äãùíü‚Ñì=3000kSZ/d‚Äãlog‚Å°zùëësubscriptsuperscriptùíükSZ‚Ñì3000ùëëùëßd\mathcal{D}^{{\rm kSZ}}_{\ell=3000}/d\log{z}. The DM model in comparison to the LO model shows a huge enhancement at z‚â≤2less-than-or-similar-toùëß2z\lesssim 2 due to nonlinear growth of structure. This enhancement, however, is mostly canceled by baryonic suppression in the Gas and FE models, making the result similar to what the LO model gives. This makes the low-zùëßz contribution relatively unimportant: only ‚àº20%similar-toabsentpercent20\sim 20\% of the signal comes from z‚â§1ùëß1z\leq 1. Although the connected term grows large relative to the unconnected ones at z‚â≤1less-than-or-similar-toùëß1z\lesssim 1, the low-zùëßz suppression keeps it to an ‚â≤10%less-than-or-similar-toabsentpercent10\lesssim 10\% level.

5. Summary and Discussion

The transverse momentum power spectrum Pq‚üÇsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} that sources the kSZ signal in the CMB anisotropy has often been computed by substituting the free electron density power spectrum PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥esubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëíùõøùõøP^{e}_{\delta\delta} acquired from simulation into Equation¬†(9). According to the equation, Pq‚üÇsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} at a given wavenumber depends sensitively on PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥subscriptùëÉùõøùõøP_{\delta\delta} at similar wavenumbers. Free electron density fluctuations at z<6ùëß6z<6 are heavily affected by nonlinear growth of structure and baryonic physics and modeling these nonlinear effects well are the key to estimating accurately the kSZ signal in the post-reionization regime. While nonlinear growth is known to be well described by the HALOFIT model, the baryonic effects are less understood due to the difficulty in implementing the physics into simulation, and are not simply amenable to semi-analytic treatments.

Although not perfectly accurate, Illustris provides a sample distribution of free electron at a high enough resolution in a large enough volume with relevant baryonic physics. Even after the end of reionization, a certain fraction of electron is locked in stars, black-holes, neutral gas, and helium. Since these are located preferentially in over-dense regions, the free electron density fluctuations are suppressed by the anti-bias as well as by the neutral fraction. Another important effect is the feedback from AGNs blowing gas out of groups and clusters, resulting in a strong extra suppression on small scales.

Since the dark matter density field is minimally affected by the baryonic effects, the window function We2=fe2‚Äã[PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥e/PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥d]subscriptsuperscriptùëä2ùëísubscriptsuperscriptùëì2ùëídelimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëíùõøùõøsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëëùõøùõøW^{2}_{e}=f^{2}_{e}[P^{e}_{\delta\delta}/P^{d}_{\delta\delta}] well separates the baryonic suppression effects on the kSZ signal. According to the window function from the Illustris simulation, the loss of gas and anti-bias suppresses the signal by ‚àº30%similar-toabsentpercent30\sim 30\% at all scales. Then the extra small-scale suppression by AGN feedback further reduces the signal at k‚â≥1‚Äãh‚ÄãMpc‚àí1greater-than-or-equivalent-toùëò1‚ÑésuperscriptMpc1k\gtrsim 1~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1} at z‚â≤1less-than-or-similar-toùëß1z\lesssim 1. This small-scale suppression is more effective for higher ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell. The net suppression in the integrated post-reionization kSZ signal ùíü‚ÑìkSZ,z<6subscriptsuperscriptùíükSZùëß6‚Ñì\mathcal{D}^{{\rm kSZ},z<6}_{\ell} is at 50‚àí60%50percent6050-60\% level at ‚Ñì=3000‚àí10000‚Ñì300010000\ell=3000-10000. We note that this small-scale suppression effect by AGN is likely over-estimated in Illustris. According Genel et¬†al. (2014), Illustris significantly undershoots the gas fraction in halos with M‚â≥1013‚ÄãM‚äôgreater-than-or-equivalent-toùëÄsuperscript1013subscriptùëÄdirect-productM\gtrsim 10^{13}M_{\odot} at z‚â≤1less-than-or-similar-toùëß1z\lesssim 1 due to exaggeration in the AGN feedback prescription and these halos are an important contributor to the density power spectrum at k‚â≥1‚Äãh‚ÄãMpc‚àí1greater-than-or-equivalent-toùëò1‚ÑésuperscriptMpc1k\gtrsim 1~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1}.

We also find the connected term, which is not accounted in Equation¬†(9), rises steeply in the nonlinear regime when we directly compute Pq‚üÇsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} from the simulation (not using Eq.¬†9), corrected for the box-size effect, when we compare with the result of evaluating Equation¬†(9). The importance of the connected term in Pq‚üÇsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} was already reported in P16 and Alvarez (2016) for the pure dark matter momentum field and for the patchy ionized density field during EoR, respectively. Here, we not only confirm its significance for the free electron momentum field, but find that the connected term in the free electron case accounts for a much higher fraction in Pq‚üÇsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} than in the pure dark matter case due to enhanced nonlinearity from the baryonic physics. At k‚â≥1‚Äãh‚ÄãMpc‚àí1greater-than-or-equivalent-toùëò1‚ÑésuperscriptMpc1k\gtrsim 1~{}h~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-1} at z‚â≤1less-than-or-similar-toùëß1z\lesssim 1, the connected term constitutes 30%percent3030\% or more of the Pq‚üÇsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} and this fraction is only a conservative lower limit given that the connected term is not box-size corrected. This is a serious warning against relying on the unconnected term (Eq.¬†9) for computing the kSZ signal. Due to the strong baryonic suppression at low-zùëßz, the connected term contribution to the integrated signal is only 6%‚Äã(12%)percent6percent126\%\,(12\%) at ‚Ñì=3000,(10000)‚Ñì300010000\ell=3000,(10000), but it may be a factor of few larger in larger simulations that are free from the box-size effect.

The resulting kSZ power spectrum is well described by a power-law fit, ùíü‚ÑìkSZ,z<6=1.38‚Äã[‚Ñì/3000]0.21‚ÄãŒº‚ÄãK2subscriptsuperscriptùíükSZùëß6‚Ñì1.38superscriptdelimited-[]‚Ñì30000.21ùúásuperscriptùêæ2\mathcal{D}^{{\rm kSZ},z<6}_{\ell}=1.38[\ell/3000]^{0.21}~{}\mu K^{2}, at ‚Ñì=3000‚àí10000‚Ñì300010000\ell=3000-10000. This is impressively close to the result of SRN12 that studied WesubscriptùëäùëíW_{e} in the same context with a different simulation. However, the results from other similar recent kSZ studies are generally higher, varying from 1.71.71.7 to 2.7‚ÄãŒº‚ÄãK22.7ùúásuperscriptùêæ22.7~{}\mu K^{2} at ‚Ñì=3000‚Ñì3000\ell=3000 as listed in Table 1.

Both with this Illustris simulation and the simulation used in SRN12, we expect the kSZ signal to be underestimated. Our work with Illustris is subject to the exaggerated AGN feedback as mentioned above and SRN12 used the L60CSF simulation that is known to over-produce stars. The results of DKS16 (2.1‚ÄãŒº‚ÄãK22.1ùúásuperscriptùêæ22.1~{}\mu K^{2}) and RVB17 (2.7‚ÄãŒº‚ÄãK22.7ùúásuperscriptùêæ22.7~{}\mu K^{2}) are however too high to be explained simply by removing the high-kùëòk suppression of the AGN feedback: applying the fe2‚Äãbe‚Äã02‚âà0.7subscriptsuperscriptùëì2ùëísubscriptsuperscriptùëè2ùëí00.7f^{2}_{e}b^{2}_{e0}\approx 0.7 factor on the DM model and ignoring the high-kùëòk suppression would yield ‚àº2.0‚ÄãŒº‚ÄãK2similar-toabsent2.0ùúásuperscriptùêæ2\sim 2.0~{}\mu K^{2}, which is still lower than those results. Another possibility is that the connected term is much larger in those works. The box-sizes used in RVB17 were 120, 240, and 480¬†h‚àí1‚ÄãMpcsuperscript‚Ñé1Mpch^{-1}~{}\rm{Mpc} and the one used in DKS16 was nearly 900‚Äãh‚àí1‚ÄãMpc900superscript‚Ñé1Mpc900~{}h^{-1}~{}\rm{Mpc}. For those larger box-sizes, the box-size effect on the connected term will be smaller. Also, a weaker AGN feedback may have resulted in the connected term contributing more at low-zùëßz than in Illustris.

To clarify these discrepancies in the literature, we need to directly compare WesubscriptùëäùëíW_{e}, fesubscriptùëìùëíf_{e}, besubscriptùëèùëíb_{e}, and the connected term in different Illustris-like high resolution gas simulations with varied feedback scenarios to calibrate the gastrophysical uncertainties in the kSZ predictions. The next round of high resolution large-sky fraction CMB experiments hold great promise for the observations, making such a concerted theoretical and simulational effort imperative. And if we can get to the point of making an accurate subtraction of the post-reionization signal from observations, we can hope to learn about the more gastrophysically complex epoch-of-reionization kSZ signal, and help to constrain EoR physics.

Appendix A CORRECTION FOR THE MISSING POWER IN THE SIMULATION BOX

As shown in Equation¬†(9), Pq‚üÇsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} is given by a convolution of PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥subscriptùëÉùõøùõøP_{\delta\delta} and Pv‚ÄãvsubscriptùëÉùë£ùë£P_{vv}. This means Pq‚üÇsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}} at a single wavenumber would receive contributions from PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥subscriptùëÉùõøùõøP_{\delta\delta} and Pv‚ÄãvsubscriptùëÉùë£ùë£P_{vv} at a range of wavenumbers. Failing to sample density and velocity mode for the whole range of wavenumbers will thus result in underestimation of Pq‚üÇsubscriptùëÉsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP_{q_{\perp}}. In simulations, finite box-size truncate the long wave contributions and can cause this problem (Zhang et¬†al., 2004; Iliev et¬†al., 2007; Park et¬†al., 2013): the integral in Equation¬†(9) is truncated for wavelengths longer than the size of the box, lbox=75‚Äãh‚àí1‚ÄãMpcsubscriptùëôbox75superscript‚Ñé1Mpcl_{\rm box}=75~{}h^{-1}~{}{\rm Mpc}.

In previous works, the truncation was often set to the fundamental mode kbox‚â°2‚ÄãœÄ/lboxsubscriptùëòbox2ùúãsubscriptùëôboxk_{\rm box}\equiv 2\pi/l_{\rm box} of the box and the missing power, Pq‚üÇmissingsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉmissingsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP^{\rm missing}_{q_{\perp}}, was then estimated by evaluating the integral for k‚Ä≤<kboxsuperscriptùëò‚Ä≤subscriptùëòboxk^{\prime}<k_{\rm box} or |ùê§‚àíùê§‚Ä≤|<kboxùê§superscriptùê§‚Ä≤subscriptùëòbox|\mathbf{k}-\mathbf{k}^{\prime}|<k_{\rm box}, assuming linear PŒ¥‚ÄãŒ¥subscriptùëÉùõøùõøP_{\delta\delta} and Pv‚ÄãvsubscriptùëÉùë£ùë£P_{vv} at k<kboxùëòsubscriptùëòboxk<k_{\rm box}. We have tested this method for the z=47ùëß47z=47 snapshot, where the density and velocity fluctuations should be in the linear regime. If the correction is accurate we are expected to recover Equation¬†(9) evaluated with linear density and velocity power spectra, which is known as the Ostriker-Vishniac spectrum (Pq‚üÇOVsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉOVsubscriptùëûperpendicular-toP^{\rm OV}_{q_{\perp}}; Efstathiou and Bond, 1987; Vishniac, 1987). The result shown as the dashed line in Figure¬†9 indicates that this correction method overshoots the correct (measured in simulation) value by ‚àº5%similar-toabsentpercent5\sim 5\%.

We can improve the correction further by adjusting the spherical truncation wavenumber with a fudge factor, fcsubscriptùëìùëêf_{c}, multiplying the reciprocal lattice cubic size kboxsubscriptùëòboxk_{\rm box}. An estimate of fcsubscriptùëìùëêf_{c} is obtained by equating the volume in a spherical octant out to fc‚Äãkboxsubscriptùëìùëêsubscriptùëòboxf_{c}k_{\rm box} to the reciprocal lattice volume, fc=(6/œÄ)1/3‚àº1.2subscriptùëìùëêsuperscript6ùúã13similar-to1.2f_{c}=(6/\pi)^{1/3}\sim 1.2, with refinements depending upon the shape of the power being integrated. We find that when we truncated the integral at fc‚Äãkboxsubscriptùëìùëêsubscriptùëòboxf_{c}k_{\rm box} with fc=1.17subscriptùëìùëê1.17f_{c}=1.17, we can suppress the error down to near a percent or less for most of the wavenumbers as described by the solid line in Figure¬†9. We note that the best-fit value for fcsubscriptùëìùëêf_{c} may be different in other simulations with different box sizes.
